newsitem.title: GREECE: NEW HEATING OIL TREAT TO EASE MAY INFLATION - NSS.
newsitem.headline: NEW HEATING OIL TREAT TO EASE MAY INFLATION - NSS.

text.p: Greece's CPI will treat heating oil as a seasonal good for the first time ever this May, ignoring a tax hike and helping push inflation lower, the general secretary of the National Statistics Service (NSS) told Reuters.
"Heating oil will be treated as a seasonal good this year and therefore May's CPI will not reflect the tax hike in heating oil," said Nickos Karavitis, general secretary at NSS.
Greece regularly raises the consumption tax on heating oil in May and cuts it in October.

Asked to gauge the impact on May's CPI from the change in the treatment of heating oil, Karavitis said he had no estimate. But he admitted that the non-inclusion of heating oil tax in CPI computations would help the disinflation process.
Press reports see inflation falling below 5.5 percent year-on-year in May from 5.9 percent in April.
Headline inflation eased to 5.9 percent year-on-year in April from 6.0 percent in March.
But core inflation which does not include food and energy prices was unchanged at 7.5 percent year-on-year in April according to foreign bank estimates.

Official figures showed that the price of heating oil surged 31.4 percent month-on-month in May 1996 when the old consumer price index using 1988 as its base year was in place. Heating oil weighed 1.753 percent in the old CPI.
Greece introduced a new CPI re-based to 1994 in January 1997. Heating oil carries a weight of 2.23 percent in the new CPI.
Economists have said that the newly constructed CPI helped lower inflation by 0.3 percent. --Dimitris Kontogiannis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4
